info.headline: Flood Advisory issued December 25 at 11:42PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1115 AM EST TUESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following counties, Henderson and Polk. * WHEN...Until 1115 AM EST Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood- prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1116 PM EST, Light to moderate rainfall has persisted across Henderson and Polk counties since yesterday morning. Doppler radar and automated gauges indicate 2-4 inches of rain has accumulated over the past 12 hours. Area streams are gradually rising and some are approaching bankfull or Action/Advisory Stage. At these levels nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas is beginning. Additional streams are likely to exceed bankfull levels during the overnight hours as rainfall and runoff continues. This includes the N Pacolet River and Green River. Therefore, a Flood Advisory has been issued and will remain in place through at least Tuesday morning. Mud Creek from Crail Farm Rd to Erkwood Dr to White St and S Center Plaza to the Oklawaha Greenway is exceeding its banks and starting to flood adjacent low-lying areas. The following streamgauge is above Action/Advisory Stage, resulting in nuisance flooding along Mud Creek... ID: MNMN7 NAME: at N Main St, 1 N Hendersonville CURRENT STAGE: 11.06 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 11.5 MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 14.0 TREND: Rising Steadily FORECAST: Mud Creek is expected to continue to rise past Action/Advisory Stage before 1 AM and may exceed Minor Flood Stage later Tuesday morning. - Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches is expected through Tuesday afternoon, with isolated totals exceeding 4 inches possible. This additional rainfall will likely cause area streams to approach and exceed Minor Flood Stage, resulting in more significant lowland flooding. If these conditions develop, a Flood Warning may be issued. Steps to protect vulnerable property adjacent to streams should be taken before flood waters develop and rise. Areas of heavier rainfall are also possible through Tuesday afternoon. Intense rainfall rates may result in an acceleration of stream rises as upper soils are already saturated from earlier rainfall. This may cause flash flooding to develop and a Flash Flood Warning may be necessary. If rapid stream rises are observed, avoid all low-lying areas near streams and be prepared to seek higher ground. - Some locations that may experience nuisance flooding include... Hendersonville, Columbus, Flat Rock, Etowah, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Tryon, Saluda, Dupont State Forest, Valley Hill, Dana, Lake Adger, East Flat Rock, Mill Spring, Tuxedo, Crab Creek and Green Creek.
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
